direction.raw_text: the ground. There on the road lies the rifle. The dust is slightly blowing across it, moved by the persistent summery little breeze. From the rifle, the CAMERA MOVES ON A LITTLE and STOPS ABRUPTLY ON the sprawled dead figure of a soldier, then another, face down in the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the dead soldiers, as the CAMERA HOLDS ON them. Near the hand of one a revolver lies, the fine dust coating it. Dust blowing over the uniforms, as though seeking to hide the shame of a murder. As it blows over their still figures, the SOUND of BIRDS coming over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a western mining town of the Eighties that has mushroomed up around a gold strike. On the streets prospectors and miners mingle with merchants. As the CAMERA PICKS UP the scene, a lumber wagon passes, bearing logs, a ten team wagon, its trailer filled with ore from the stamp mills and bearing the legend: ARGUS MINE. A stage coach comes in as we: DISSOLVE INT. HOTEL - NIGHT On the hotel clerk, as he sits behind the desk, playing a guitar and singing pensively the ballad of the story. As he sings, JOHN HAVEN, newly arrived on the stagecoach, walks in, gazes at the clerk with a slight smile, finding the clerk completely indifferent to the arrival of anybody, at last leaves the bag and saunters out. DISSOLVE EXT. SALOON - NIGHT As Haven leaves the hotel and has reached the saloon, a well- lighted, plush-looking spot, illumined by kerosene flares. Sticking a pipe in his mouth, Haven saunters in.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FADE OUT FADE IN ROCK PASS

direction.raw_text: It is a huge elaborate room, lit by overhead chandeliers. A long mahogany bar runs the length of it. To one side there is a big stove and the gambling tables. Beyond can be seen pool tables in an alcove. To another side, a man grinds away at a piano. A stairway near the end of the bar leads to an upper floor. The place is crowded and noisy with people. Haven saunters towards the dice table, pauses, watches; he is looking the crowd over carefully -- missing no detail of the place or the people in it. When his turn comes, he picks up the dice, bets all over the place -- on the line, on the odds, on the seven, then on the come, the hard way, etc. His point is eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven bets again, doubling all over the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Players glance at the newcomer. Prince appears from nowhere, standing behind the stickman, watching. Prince is slender, black-haired, handsome and impassive. Haven throws again. Stellman, an Army officer, watches curiously. There is a little rising murmur as Haven tosses another natural. He does it without enthusiasm or any lost movement. The bettors get down on him. Prince touches the stickman's arm; the man stands aside and Prince takes his place with the stick. Prince tosses the dice back to Haven. Haven's eyes are fixed on him. With a little smile, Haven throws the dice to the next man, picks up his winnings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes meet Prince's again and then he turns away, Prince's gaze following him curiously, Stellman looks at Prince.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eight the hard way! Pay the line!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven a winner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thanks...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just seems kind of free with that money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven, as still smiling slightly, he heads towards the bar, searching the faces of the crowd as he goes. Two miners are squared off for a fight and Haven, going his way, walks between them, very indifferent, not even glancing back at the SOUND of scuffle behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Haven alone is not watching the fight. All the others have turned to see it; even the barman is busy watching. But Haven's eyes are resting on the figure of a woman now at the piano, singing. Softly, as if to herself and for her own enjoyment. He is near the end of the bar and near the piano, and since no one else listens to her at this moment, she sings, half smiling, directly for him, and then, self-consciously, she stops and turns to sit at a table, as Haven watches her. Behind them the fight is being stopped and Charlie's eyes follow the huge bouncer, Mick Marion, as he drags the offenders out to the door and the street. All is as usual. The bartender is back at work. As Haven turns, he finds that the place beside him is now occupied by the young Lieutenant (Phil Stellman). Haven glances at the uniform, then at the pleasant face of the officer, as the barman comes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A girl sidles up to him, blonde, brash and pretty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his back to her; she gives him a look and saunters off. The barman produces the drinks -- a beer for Stellman, the young officer. The barman folds his arms. Stellman looks at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The barman turns to get it. Stellman is still looking at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The barman gives Haven another Rye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The barman, listening, senses trouble and signals with his eyes to a big bouncer down the bar. The bouncer moves up quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stare at each other for a long second, then Stellman speaks icily:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stellman's jaw tightens; then he turns and exits abruptly. The barman sighs with relief; the bouncer turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away from the bar, after flipping a coin on to it, while the barman stands there not knowing whether to be angry or philosophical.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to barman) Whiskey -- like you'd pour it for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you know it's no fun to drink alone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not till after the first one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You a stranger here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to barman, after gulping it in one gulp) What kind of whiskey was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the bottle it says Rye -- but the way you take it, I don't see what difference it makes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another Rye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (easily) You didn't answer my question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a stranger everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, soldier. I know that one, too. Got a job, stranger? No? Why don't you join the Army? Three meals a day, a place to sleep, a nice warm uniform -- STELLMAN It has a little more than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deliberately) Yeah, it has one thing more, and that's what I could never take -- (looking at Stellman's stripes) It's got Second-Lieutenants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you want to make it a personal matter -- HAVEN (coldly) I don't make it anything, soldier. You tried to sell something and I didn't buy it -- so why don't you just beat it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I weren't in uniform, I might teach you some manners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you could teach me anything, you wouldn't be in a uniform.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You couldn't be looking for trouble, could you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could, but I'm not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine, because this is one of the best places West of the Atlantic Ocean to find it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was my first impression.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Haven looks at him) That Lieutenant's a nice young boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't doubt it, but his mouth is too big -- like your ears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven, as he threads his way through the tables towards the door. His eyes catch sight of the girl who sang at the piano, Charlie. She is sitting at a table with Prince. Prince murmurs to her and she glances at Haven, then looks away again. Haven notes it. As he comes near the table, the blonde who spoke to him at the bar, accosts him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven is looking at Charlie. She is checking a stack of coins the blonde has turned in to her. She glances up with a fleeting smile at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their gazes meet and Prince notes it with narrowing eyes. The gaze holds like a spell, and then Charlie's smile comes back, from nowhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven looks at her, fascinated. She can feel a fascination herself. Now Haven smiles a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him in a second's silence. Haven turns and leaves. She watches him go. Prince studies her face, his own grim. A croupier comes up and places a paper before her. She hardly notices it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie snaps out of it long enough to initial the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away. Prince sits still, his eyes on Charlie, his slim fingers at an habitual trick, that of idly stacking dice in a little pillar and then picking the pillar aloft by holding the lowest dice pinched between the thumb and forefinger, NOT by the edges, but by the sides. Now he does it as he watches Charlie's face. Her eyes glance again at the disappearing back of Haven. The sense of fascination seems to have gotten her, too. Then she realizes the presence of Prince and his shrewd gaze. She looks at him coolly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince flips the dice into his palm and rises...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How is it now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drinking alone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flipping her a coin) It's all right -- try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a good habit if it makes you pick fights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only with Second Lieutenants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We like Second Lieutenants here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see -- here everybody fights, except the Army.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't know -- CHARLIE (still smiling) So anyone who doesn't like the Army -- HAVEN I know what you mean, but I'm afraid I'll have to come back. I like the way you sing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's his limit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a sucker getting hot with the dice at Ed's table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- cool him off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The board sidewalk has given way to a rutty dirt road. Now the racket of the saloon street is just a ghost of noise, the road dark and silent. Haven has emerged from the saloon. He glances up the street. Fifty yards ahead, Stellman is walking slowly. Stellman pauses, shoots a quick glance backwards, then goes on. Haven follows, going leisurely up the street after Stellman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a corner as Stellman turns it, pauses and waits. When Haven reaches it, Stellman goes on in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CASLON'S MINE-CABIN - NIGHT As Stellman reaches it, pauses and glances behind him. Then he rings a bell. Haven comes up and waits in silence, glancing at the dark interior. A woman's face now peers through the door window and then the door opens. Stellman enters quickly and Haven follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CASLON'S MINE-CABIN - NIGHT As Stellman and Haven follow Mrs. Caslon to a rear door. Looking around, Haven notes in the shadows a desk and in a corner the big safe. (This room is described in a subsequent scene.) So as to emit the least light, Mrs. Caslon lets Stellman and Haven go through, then quickly follows them and quickly shuts the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CASLON'S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT It is remarkably neat and elegant inside. As Haven, glancing around, pauses inside, he finds himself facing a burly uniformed cavalry officer, captain's bars gleaming on the side of his collar. The captain is big and broad and scowling. He is standing by the fireplace and his eyes are boring into Haven's with curiosity and perhaps, suspicion. Stellman steps forward as Haven and the captain are measuring each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven gives a casual nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles looks him up and down. Haven hands him an envelope which he slips into his tunic without removing his gaze from Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They eye each other, Iles scowling, Haven thinly smiling. The sense of conflict is already between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods and smiles warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits down. Iles is still studying Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven nods agreeably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles pulls out a cigar, lights it, sizing Haven up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a tight little silence, while Iles formulates his dislike for this newcomer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven takes out his pipe and fills it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the first time Iles looks amicably at him, as though realizing that after all the man isn't there to criticize him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles slightly at Iles, who gives him a slight smile in return, somehow intrigued by this nonchalance. Haven rises from the chair, lighting the dead pipe in vain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven glances at Mrs. Caslon, smiles back at Iles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles marches out abruptly, followed by Stellman. The door shuts. Haven smiles after him, then at Mrs. Caslon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens again, smartly, Iles marches back in, kisses Mrs. Caslon on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he marches out again, shutting the door after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes over to a sideboard and pours a little from a decanter into two wine glasses. Haven watches her. For the first time he realizes she is a very attractive woman. She smiles as she brings him the wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven nods and they sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts for the door and she follows him. At the open door he pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven walks out and she closes the door thoughtfully and turns away. In a moment the door opens and Haven reenters and crosses to her much in the manner that we have seen Captain Iles do so. Haven stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and goes out the door. Mrs. Caslon stands smiling after him. The smile fades for a moment -- then she dismisses it with a shrug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET - NIGHT As Haven saunters along. He pauses, glances up at a sign that reads: HOTEL. Then he enters the dingy building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Captain Iles -- the Commanding Officer of the Post.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Haven -- sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see you finally got here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) I seem to finally get everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (introducing) Mrs. Caslon, -- Mr. Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've met Mr. Stellman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It came off beautifully. He picks a very good fight. In fact, I think I'm still a little sore at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grunting) Sit down, Mr. Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you're operating under sealed orders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgruntled) All this mumbo jumbo is characteristic of the Military Information Department.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We use it as sparingly as possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been in this territory for a number of years -- and I think it might be a little rougher here than a suburb of Washington, D.C.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very possibly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why is M.I.D. sending you out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because two soldiers have been murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And they think I can't handle that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They merely know you haven't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have only ninety-four men on the post, with Indian trouble up north. The War Department has refused to send reinforcements, or am I boring you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking bored) I'm not the War Department.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explaining) The two soldiers were killed while escorting one of the gold stages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Is escorting gold a function of your command?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young man, the functions of my command look very pretty on paper, but they're not very practical in a territory like this. Do you have any illusions about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no illusions about anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's happening to the gold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've permitted it to be stored in a warehouse on the post. Now everybody is waiting to see what I do next.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you do next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with sarcasm) Aren't you here to tell me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lighting the pipe) Captain, you're in a bad way. (going over to discard the match) Wells Fargo won't convoy gold. You tried and failed and two men are dead. The gold is piling up on the post and you can't move it. Your post is under-manned. You want the Quartermaster at Platte to replace seventy uniforms sent to the freight office at West Rim City -- ILES The freight building burned down with the uniforms! I'm not operating a fire department -- and if I was, West Rim City is sixty miles away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That doesn't concern me either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The killing of two soldiers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were my men, Haven, and I'm trying every way I know to find out who murdered them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So will I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll find it harder than you think. I don't know how you operate, but it's a dangerous job that can get you killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps I can get some help from the Sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can forget him. He's a miserable man that somebody is using to keep the law a joke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make it sound very difficult. Why don't you just wrap up your flag and take it back East with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smarting) Tell me, how will I know what you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll let you know from time to time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) That's very obliging of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I don't want to visit the Army post.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then report to me through Mrs. Caslon here. You can be a friend of her husband's. He owned the Argus mine and died last year. If that meets your approval.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only if it meets with hers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I'd be delighted to help. (she smiles at Haven)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grim at the smile) Is that all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON He really isn't that abrupt -- he --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (warmly) Goodnight, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON You see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I think he secretly likes you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a man who can sure keep a secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (smiles) Would you like a little sherry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only if you have some too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON To your good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What mine did the two soldiers try to convoy the gold from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON My mine -- The Argus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling a little) That brings me to a question I decided not to ask.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (smiling back at him) Then I'll answer it first. Captain Iles has asked me to marry him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can understand that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (quietly) But you can't understand why Captain Iles should be involved in the gold business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I do now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON It isn't just mine. You must realize there's a lot of gold from all over the territory stored at the post warehouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Perhaps as much as half a million. (worried now) In fact, I have about fifty thousand in my safe now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is doing all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I don't know... that's the worst part of it... not knowing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puts down the glass, pats her shoulder with casual reassurance) I might find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Don't get into trouble -- HAVEN That's why I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I know, but -- HAVEN Don't worry about it. Trouble and I are old enemies. We understand each other. (he grins at her) Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (smiling again) Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't tell me your husband's name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Ben.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (repeating it) Ben.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven enters the small dismal lobby, and goes over to the desk, where a little man, Orville Weekly sits, singing to himself softly and strumming an accompaniment on a battered guitar. As Haven stands there the clerk finishes the verse about the stranger. Haven nods approval. The clerk looks at him shrewdly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven puts down the money; the clerk spins the registry to him, watches as Haven signs it. And he can read that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk spits, hands him a key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven crosses to exit into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S SALOON - NIGHT As Haven enters. It is crowded. Haven pauses by a table. He sees Charlie at the piano singing. He sees Mick cross to Prince and say something, then Prince gazes in his direction. Haven's eyes meet those of Prince suddenly turned to him, cold as glass. Charlie, seeing that Haven is watching and listening to her impromptu singing, stops and makes her way through the crowd towards a booth off the dance floor. Haven's eyes follow her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Evenin' stranger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must know everybody in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody but one. I don't know you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name? You seem to be a pretty clever fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Orville Weekly, and I can't be a total blank. I been here six years and I ain't dead yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you got a vacant room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Day, week, month?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't always know. And the way you talk a man couldn't be very sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it's eight bucks, cash in advance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From Arizona, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I always put down where I'm going next -- so I won't forget.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Room ten -- end of the hall. Make your own bed. Furnish your own towels. Your bag's over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (picking up the key) Thanks a lot for the key. I'll be back later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - of booth as Charlie sits down. A sandwich is waiting for her. She takes a bite of it, then glances up to see Haven standing beside the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie glances at him, then at the crowd where Mick Marion stands beside Prince. Both are looking coldly towards the booth. Haven's gaze follows hers towards Mick, as Prince leaves the big man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles slightly back at him, glances away towards Mick. Haven looks too, curiously. Mick is still watching, coldly. Others glance too, as though this were an unexpected thing. Mick takes a drink from a passing waiter; kills it in one gulp. Haven looks back at Charlie's face and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter nods and leaves. Charlie is still gazing at Haven with that slight provocative smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter leaves, as Charlie still regards Haven with a curious interest. Haven is glancing again toward Mick, just as that animal barrels down another whiskey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment Prince comes into scene and sits at the table. Haven looks at him but Charlie offers no introduction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances up and a slow smile comes over his face as Mick Marion is seen approaching deliberately and with cold menace. Her eyes follow his, then back to his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blank-faced and big, Mick arrives at the booth. He stares from Charlie to Haven. Haven looks at him then at Charlie. Charlie watches Haven's face, but the smile remains. It seems to sway her, this little test of expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick is not quite sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven senses now it is a little game they're playing together on him. His smile remains. He reaches for the bottle, his hand grasping the base of it, just as Mick reaches for it too, clenching the top. Mick lifts at it; Haven's hand holds. They look at each other as this little game of strength goes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That does it. Mick wrenches at the bottle, and as he does so, Haven releases his grip. The bottle shoots up. The wine spills over Mick's face and clothes. Infuriated, Mick flings the bottle at Haven, but Haven ducks as he comes out of the chair. The bottle crashes against the wall, and Haven's fist crashes against Mick. The big man grunts and staggers back, but he doesn't drop. As Haven sets himself, he is suddenly pinned from behind by two bouncers. Mick stands still, staring at him, his cut lip bleeding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a dead silence. At the crap table the dice read seven but no one looks at them, all turning toward the scene. A minor rises and the girl on his lap hits the floor. A drunk steals a drink and no one sees him. (Business with glass) Prince looks on coldly. Mark Bristow, moving up from the dice table, pauses and stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two bouncers start with Haven toward the door, Mick following. A rear rises and men begin following in their silent wake. Only the guy at the piano keeps on playing: he never stops.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How about eating alone? Is that a bad habit too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just when you have to pay for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only money. (sitting down) I've changed my mind since I left here awhile ago. I don't want to pick a fight -- or break the bank -- or -- CHARLIE (evenly) What changed your mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) That's what I came back to find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it would be better if you found another girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) No, it wouldn't... I looked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That man in ape's clothing -- could he be Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His eyes follow you around like a couple of flies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They follow me to see that strangers don't annoy me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only strangers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one else would be so foolish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First, you're beautiful. Then I like the way you sing -- and now you're a woman of mystery. (to a passing waiter) Champagne?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to be a stranger, so I'll have to be foolish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You like to take chances, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I feel lucky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I'd advise you to try the dice table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd rather get lucky here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugging) Every man has a right to go to his own funeral.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as the waiter sets down the champagne and glasses) I could be your cousin from Waxahatchio. I could be cousin John, a missionary on his way to China.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He seems to be a lot of man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The most in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a very small town. (he sips and gazes around) You could get it all in this saloon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We usually do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So Charlie probably runs the town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (toying with his dice) Why do you care?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to spend some time here. I want to know who winds the clock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's been a nice conversation. I hate to have it end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a taut pause) Mick -- this is -- cousin John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relieved) From Waxahatchie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's keeping him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he's wondering if he couldn't do more good here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You aren't very friendly, are you, mister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quoting) A friend to all is a friend to none.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to learn not to pick 'em so easy, like you do your cousins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Charlie) Ask her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coolly) I never saw him before in my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (icily) You're too little to make that big a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to correct me or just bleed at the mouth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Bring him outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on Charlie as she rises. Bristow and Prince have sauntered over to her as the place empties, leaving only the piano player.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince lets go with one of his rare smiles as he looks admiringly at Charlie. They reach the door. The crowd opens for them a little.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casually) A misunderstanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you find out what he wants?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting out) He wanted to be my cousin. (they follow her) Only I haven't any aunts or uncles. (still casually) But you never know -- and the least I can do is bury him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Mick and Haven come out; the crowd makes a noisy clearing. There are bets going down. As soon as the crowd has formed an open space, Haven wheels and smacks Mick across the face hitting with the heel of the hand, so that Mick rocks back almost going down. There is dead silence. Mick sets himself for the Kill, as he peels his coat. Bristow is shaking with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they stare at the fight -- FULL SHOT - fight scene. As Mick is slowly advancing toward Haven. He suddenly swings a haymaker which Haven easily ducks, another and another that Haven evades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick misses again, fiercely and Haven cracks him one in the midriff. Then steps out fast and waits. Mick charges and Haven catches him full in the mouth. It stops Mick, and then Haven socks him again, this time with the butt of his hand -- open palm -- on the nose. Mick is surprised, tasting the blood on his hurt lips.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mick will kill him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's ten to one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) I don't like the other fellow's chances, but I'm a sucker for odds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should always bet on a champion. Then you can only lose once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You give ten to one...? (she nods) I'll take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're down. A thousand to a hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't miss so much. You'll got tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on Charlie, Mark and Prince, as they watch. Charlie's eyes are fixed with a kind of admiration on Haven. Prince watches without interest. Mark is tense and excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you feel she wishes it might...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He can fight a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little won't be enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on the fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Mick closes again, Haven stops quickly to one side, clipping him behind the ear as he goes by. But this time Mick keeps after Haven and finally connects. It is more of a push than a clean hit, but even so the force of it drives Haven off balance and he sprawls on his back. As Mick, sensing victory, charges, Haven knows he can't get to his feet in time, so he turns his body and springs at Mick's knees shoulder first. The impact spills Mick on his face; before he can recover, Haven dives on him, hands flat on his own chest and palms turned out. His body crashes heavily, angling across Mick's head, and Haven's savagely pushing hands mash the other man's face into the hard ground. Then he rolls clear and comes to his feet, breathing easily, waiting. Mick gets up, shaking his head to clear it, mad and hurt. As he closes ponderously in on Haven, his booted foot suddenly shoots out. Haven twists his knee cap away but takes the blow on the inside of his thigh, numbing the leg so that he almost goes down. And now Mick gets to him. His great arms close around Haven's waist, his hands locked in the small of Haven's back. Haven braces himself against the crushing squeeze, tensing his back muscles and stiffening his spine, but there is nothing he can do against the implacable brute power of the other man. The sweat stands out on Haven's face as Mick's great strength bends him over farther and farther. He must do something, and soon, or his back will be cracked like a barrel stave. Suddenly he bends his knees and lifts his feet up from off the ground. Mick, suddenly finding Haven's full weight pulling him forward, crashes down on top of him. With all the strength left in him, Haven brings his knee to the pit of Mick's stomach; as Mick's hold breaks, Haven rolls clear. Now they are both hurt. Haven's ribs and chest are so bruised that it is agony to take a breath. He knows it has to end quickly or he is done for, and he goes all out. As Mick tries to close with him again, he stands his ground and throws pile-driver punches to Mick's midsection; as Mick finally lowers his arms to cover his body, Haven shifts his attack to the face. This is not Mick's style of fighting, but as he lashes back clumsily and angrily, each time he touches Haven it is with punishing power. Toe to toe, they slug it out, the belt now unwound and dangling from Mick's fist, both men groggy but both refusing to go down. Finally Mick is helpless to protect himself, but Haven hasn't got power left to knock him off those sturdy legs. Gathering himself, Haven hurls his body shoulder first at Mick's chest but he miscalculates, glances off and falls flat on his face. As he rolls over, dogged and slow with exhaustion, he sees that his weight has staggered Mick; the big man has taken a step back, and now he starts to walk forward. Dazed and blind with pain, he passes Haven, staggers forward until the tie-rail stops him. There he stands, his hands on the rail, moving his head from side to side like a wounded animal. The crowd is silent now, waiting. Haven gets to his feet, drunk with weariness. He puts a hand on Mick's shoulder, but hasn't the strength to whirl him around. He braces himself with one hand against the tie-rail, and almost in slow motion pulls Mick around and clips him one last time with his remaining strength. Mick goes down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before he is up he goes down again, unable to make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd is transfixed. They can't even cheer. The two bouncers lean over the fallen Mick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pick up Mick as Haven stupidly watches. Then as Haven turns and goes away, swaying and weak, the roar rises. He pushes aside people who try to assist him. They move aside and watch him leave. The crowd goes back in the saloon behind the vanquished Mick...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stand still and fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up very slow) You can't do this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the dirt) Nobody can do this... to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody just did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on Charlie, Bristow and Prince. Prince watches the beaten Mick go by with a smile of contempt. Charlie's eyes are fixed on the vanishing lonely figure of Haven. Mark's eyes are dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bristow follows Prince, wiping his forehead. Charlie remains, looking down the now empty street where Haven vanished, a strange soft look in her eyes, a slow smile mounting her lips.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe it. Mick Marion losing a fight and me winning a thousand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Prince) Give it to him, Prince -- in chips.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Orville behind his desk is strumming softly on the guitar, his eyes following Haven as the latter slowly and somewhat painfully walks in and across the lobby. All the way to the desk the clerk watches Haven, strumming softly. Haven pauses and smiles very faintly at him. The clerk puts the guitar aside. There is a coffee pot and cup on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orville pours it quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orville pours the "cream" from a whiskey bottle. Haven sips gingerly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finishes the coffee, turns and starts for his room. Orville tosses two towels on Haven's shoulder as the latter goes. Strumming the guitar again softly, he watches with admiration the retreating form of Haven.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning on the desk) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning back to pick up a pitcher and a bottle) They told me who was fightin'. I was getting ready to rent your room. Cream or sugar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking with mild curiosity and admiration) Myself, I'd rather fight a forest fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) So would I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven stands in the darkness only lighted by lights of the saloon next door. He stands there looking vaguely out the window, sucking his knuckles absently as he listens to the piano playing. Then he goes wearily to the bed and falls on it gratefully, shutting his eyes, the towels still across his shoulder. There is a moment of silence and then a soft KNOCK at the door. Another KNOCK, and painfully Haven lifts himself on one elbow and drags out his gun. The door opens and Charlie enters. She shuts it behind her and stands looking at him. He lets the gun fall and turns over on his back. Charlie walks across to the bed and stands looking down at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts it on the table beside the bed. Haven's eyes follow her. She sees the towels, takes them to the washstand, soaks them and brings them back and compresses them gently on Haven's bruised face. When she takes the towel away, he pulls himself up a little, propped against the pillow, looking at her curiously. She sits down on the edge of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her as she wets the towels again, returns and wraps his hands in them, sitting again on the edge of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is almost asleep. She takes the now unused towel and puts it back in the basin, soaks it, returns with it and tucks it against the side of his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is sound asleep the next second. She stares at him; rises, puts the blanket over him and goes quietly out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL LOBBY - DAY Haven comes to the desk from his room. Orville is singing another verse of the ballad. The clerk favors Haven with an admiring smile. The coffee pot is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orville strums the strings as Haven drinks, having a little trouble with his sore hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off. Orville ponders this, scowling into space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MRS. CASLON'S MINE-CABIN Iles is pacing the floor. Mrs. Caslon is occupied with some minor domestic chore. Stellman is standing by the door. Iles is a ball of fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stellman shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a knock at the door. Iles gives her a look; then glares at Stellman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stellman opens the door and Haven walks in. He pauses, glances around and smiles. Mrs. Caslon smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and nods. Irons. Haven can feel the surcharged air. Deliberately he assumes that casual manner that so burns the Captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles glances sharply at Mrs. Caslon, and then to Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven sits, wincing a little. But he beams at Iles, who now picks a book off the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven inspects his knuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses the book on the table, glaring at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles scowls to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven goes to the door, gently touching his sore jaw. At the door he turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles and leaves, closing the door as he goes. Iles stands there frozen with rage a moment. Then his face relaxes in a grim smile. He glances at Stellman as he takes a cigar out and bites it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SALOON - DAY Business is slack. Girls drink coffee and knit at a table. Ernie polishes glasses at the bar. A colored man cleans a crap table. All look up with curiosity and esteem as Haven enters; all but Sam, the piano player, who goes on playing. Haven goes to the bar. Ernie nods at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven goes to the stairs. The eyes of the girls follow him. Top of the stairs -- as Haven reaches the door, wincing at the climb. He KNOCKS with the heel of his hand, hurts it, then uses his boot toe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How do you feel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like a million dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just cost me a thousand. You lost your pipe in the fight. I brought it to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you always get sweet with the men who fight over you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only the winners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me something -- CHARLIE (quietly, smiling) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he lies back) That fellow might have killed me -- (sleepily) Where do you bury the losers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You talk too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) What do you want -- the next dance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you'd better sit this one out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The way you run this dump I knew you must be good at something else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some call me the town poet -- and some the village idiot. Who am I to question either? How you feel today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I crawled here from Kansas City.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it figures to make you pretty famous. Fact, people been askin' for you already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That gold mine lady -- Mrs. Caslon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couldn't do better. And Charlie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. less.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem impressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Charlie owns a piece of everything, includin' the undertaker and the sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The stage line too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything but the Wednesday Bible Class. Even owns a piece of me. (grins) Takes your money while you're here, and makes you pay to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting down the cup) When you get the next verse I'd like to hear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't find no word to rhyme with Mick Marion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he turns away) Carrion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of all the stupid bonehead plays! What did he fight about -- don't tell me a woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what they tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who started it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, but Haven finished it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That probably strikes you as a very admirable thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't think so! I have men who can use their fists. Why didn't they send a man who could use his brains!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- open it up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mrs. Caslon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Captain... Lieutenant...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Mr. Haven, we may not have very much around here that pleases you, but we do have a strict post regulation against brawling in the town. Now would you like to explain what happened last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I came here to return Mrs. Caslon's call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating a chair) Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This book I have in my hand is the Army Register, 1882.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am now going to read from it. (finds the place; reads) "Haven, John Martin, born Ohio 1852. Appointed Second Lieutenant. Promoted First Lieutenant 20th Infantry, March 1880; reduced in rank to 2nd Lieutenant January 12, 1881."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the Army Register.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven, you've lost your rank once. It may very well happen again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To almost anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Maybe if you'd let him explain... He might have a good reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even a bad reason would delight me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you like to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you pick that fight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those things can become very vague.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrewdly) And where do you expect all this to get you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising wearily) That is a question I prefer not to answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snaps it) I think you're trying to carry your authority too far.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps, but there's one thing, Captain Iles... We had an arrangement that we wouldn't meet -- you and I -- except through Mrs. Caslon... I think it's important to keep it that way... (one more glance back) And I like it better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't he ever stop playing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sam? It don't bother him. He's deaf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do I find the boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First door top of the stairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mick been around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's undisposed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This is a big corner room, the windows of which look out over the main street. The chairs are big and there is a roll- top desk in the corner, a big leather sofa, and on the walls some framed pictures. At a table Prince sits. He has six dice stacked on top of each other and he is lifting the column. Charlie is seated behind the desk smiling. Haven looks from one to the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seems to enjoy Haven's momentary confusion. Prince is indifferent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince gives him a thin smile and rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince saunters out. Haven sits in a big chair, very gingerly; takes out his pipe and tobacco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes over with one and lights his pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his hand and looks at the cut knuckle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks out of the room and he watches her; then around the room. In a moment she returns, pulls up a chair in the front of him and sits down. She has bandages and a little jar of ointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes one of his bruised hands, and as she bandages his hands slowly, carefully and rather expertly, they talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles at him and then goes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands up. Haven looks at her and ignores his bandaged hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven gets the meaning and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she writes out the authorization, Haven saunters to the window, then over to the desk. Charlie finishes and hands him the paper. Haven scans it, pockets it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven is moving to the door and she beside him. They pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her face, neck and hair. She looks pretty good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven looks squarely at her a moment, then smiles. He reaches out one bandaged hand and pats her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out, and Charlie remains standing there, staring after him, just a little hazily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAGE LINE DEPOT - DAY As Haven walks through the wide gate into a compound. There are several unhitched stages and freight wagons, one or two in partial disassembly and being serviced. A colored boy is readying a horse and buggy and beside him, overlooking the yard activities, is a bespectacled man with rubber sleeve garters. He is the manager. He has eyes like Armadillo and claw-like hands; otherwise, he could be your loan agency man. Seeing Haven he crosses to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The manager glances at the note, after moving his spectacles out of the way. He gives it back without a word, and turns toward the rear office door. Haven halts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim Goddard and Jerry enter from the rear office door. Jerry is the younger. Goddard walks a little stiffly with the aid of a cane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They halt and look at Haven. The Manager jerks a thumb at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven nods, after a glance at the manager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out, looking back with an awesome smile. Haven looks curiously at Goddard, who has been standing in silence, a thin smile on his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He obeys. Haven watches and then turns to the manager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The manager, gives them to him. Then looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, takes a few steps -- and turns back to Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The manager turns to go, shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Prince) You wanted to see me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They said Charlie -- CHARLIE Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. (nods toward Prince) This is Prince. Don't ever gamble with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean with his equipment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She means either. (he crosses to door) See you later, Charlie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You surround yourself with very affable characters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It makes me feel at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not that sinister. Last night with the wet towels you were Florence Nightingale in silk stockings. (stretching his legs, looking at her) Have you got a match?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's one in my pocket but I hate to reach for it... thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Now you're Florence Nightingale again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did you pick that fight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could have insisted I was your cousin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps that isn't the way I felt about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as his knuckle hurts) Ouch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where did you get the name of Charlie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was my father's. My name is Charlene, but --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like that better... Charlene... (she doesn't answer) This'll be the first time I ever worked for a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (giving him a glance) What makes you think you're going to work for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sent for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing the bandage) How's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking towards the window) All right, I sent for you. I was doing a nice quiet business. That was because everybody was afraid of Mick. Now every time a man has enough drinks in him to feel rugged he'll try to do what you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But they will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not the job I want. I don't intend to start at the bottom. I've been there. It's too crowded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coolly) Where do you want to start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what will you do for it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything -- except hang. How did you get -- all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I learned one thing from my father. As long as men think they can beat the tables, all you have to do is get a table. Sometimes they run out of cash and I find myself with new responsibilities.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Such as -- CHARLIE A couple of stores for one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't see myself behind a counter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A sawmill, and a logging camp. The logging camp's a long way from town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I own the stage line from here to West Rim City, but that's a dud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Outlaws. The money was in gold shipments. Now the mines won't ship it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take that job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean ride shot-gun?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean run the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't force your luck. You won a fight last night. You could lose one tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today I'd hate to tangle with a butterfly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think you'll get out of running the stage line?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A commission on all the gold I get through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That should buy you a small beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Glad to get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's pretty dangerous. Even Wells Fargo locked up their station and quit trying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leveling) Who steals the gold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who doesn't? All they have to do is put a mask on and they all look like Black Bart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) Give me a letter of authorization.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going to the desk) I can't bet against you twice, can I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling at him) You know I forgot to ask you one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm working for you now. You can ask me anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do I know I can trust you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only with money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Okay, boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking him over) Are you the manager?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard about you. You're the fellah who took Mick Marion apart. (looking at him) Almost knocked me off my feet. But my feet ain't been any good since I followed Stonewall Jackson. (keenly) What business you got with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing him the note) I'm the new boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute. You're not fired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got to be. There ain't enough work around here for one man, let alone two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two can loaf as easy as one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Leonard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk to him. He just took the reins. (indicating the two lads) This is Jim Goddard. He's a regular stage driver. Jerry here runs freight to the sawmill. Boys, your new boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a grin of hero worship) I gotta start out of here for the sawmill before daybreak. Is that all right, Mr. Haven?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seen that fight last night. It was sure a beauty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Glad you enjoyed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I liked was the way you -- HAVEN Let's not talk about it. Right now it hurts my hands to listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My last run. I stopped a bullet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you get a look at them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish I had.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'm going to need you and not on one leg. So sit down and give it a rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly smiling) Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm coming back later and sit behind your desk. I'll need the keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking keys from his pocket) Only things here that work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son, I waste my time. I might as well waste some advice. You're full of blood and vinegar, but this whole thing has got something wrong with it. Goddard only got nicked in the shin. You might not be so lucky...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might depend on something besides luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like for instance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well the fact that they don't seem to shoot too straight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't need to when they shoot so often.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Worry it over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven, whistling softly, crosses to the colored boy who is polishing the last specks of dust off the buggy. It is a beautiful buggy attached to a beautiful horse. Haven pauses and gazes at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The colored boy steps back and admires his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven climbs in the buggy, and the Colored Boy watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S OFFICE - DAY Charlie is dressed to go somewhere. She looks much nicer in these clothes than in her show garments of the night. She is listening to Prince who sits in a chair, the inevitable dice in his fingers, two this time. There is a silence except the rattle of the cubes. Then Prince speaks coldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up, goes to the window testily. Prince looks at her coldly as she gazes at the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks straight at her and she stares back, staring him down at last. As his eyes lower, she turns again to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is silent and Prince gets up and walks out. She does not turn. Down in the street she can see Haven riding up in the buggy, and the hard look on her face softens to a smile as Haven climbs out of the buggy. Some people passing stare at him, and whisper together. His fame has spread. He walks inside, smiling a little.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sumpin', ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's it for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Charlie, Mr. Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you drive her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same places. Around the hills, down the river, every afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'll give you this afternoon off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I shouldn't let you do this, suh... (looking Haven over, especially the bandaged hands) But ah am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does this Haven move me out? Is that the plan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prince, you know I wouldn't part with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I always come up empty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite empty. I gave you what is probably the one honest feeling you ever had in your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I keep forgetting that. Pardon me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Prince?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like John Haven or anything about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've said that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to have him looked up in the Social Register?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man walks in out of nowhere -- CHARLIE (turning) And went against your table. Did he play like a gambler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knew something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- and he took Mick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So he can fight. (shrewdly) You like that part, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you one thing, Prince, I don't like this part.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven enters. There is no play at the tables. Some at the bar. The deaf pianist is pounding the keys softly. Prince has just descended the stairs and gone to the dice table, where he leans, his cold eyes fixed on Haven as the latter goes to the foot of the stairs. At this moment Charlie appears and descends the stairs, adjusting her hat. Haven stares at her with admiration, as she descends, smiling at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Haven and Charlie, as she reaches the last step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his arm instead and they walk towards the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stand there a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every time I see you, you look different, but you always look beautiful. Why is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I always have somebody to lie to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take my hand -- (offering it) But don't squeeze it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Charlie and Haven, as they go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me what you're doing with my buggy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My work. I'm the new transportation boss. You hired me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Prince, as he stands at the table, watching them go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven helps Charlie into the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven shrugs and turns the carriage to front of Bristow's office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I presume you're going shopping?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't wear anything sold this side of Chicago. I'm going to call on a gentleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At this hour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name is Mark Bristow -- and any hour, it would be strictly business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The way you say it -- he may need a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a lawyer himself, but it won't help him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a smile) What good is a lawyer if he never gets in a court?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like a doctor in a graveyard. Where is this unlucky man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Across the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The letters on the window read: Mark Bristow, Lawyer As Haven pulls up in front of it with the carriage. He goes around and helps Charlie alight, making it a little slow for the sake of added intimacy and causing her to smile as though she didn't resent it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Charlie starts in, Mrs. Caslon comes out and they pass. Mrs. Caslon pauses to smile and Haven tips his hat. Charlie, flashing a backward look, sees this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I take the horses back and rub them down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think they've gone far enough?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then maybe you better wait and come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Haven and Mrs. Caslon. Haven is talking to her with apparent casualness because he realizes that Charlie can see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her face as she thinks it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and Haven pats her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder if you'd do me a favor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Why, surely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a big favor, and I wouldn't blame you if you refused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to haul some gold from your mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON That IS a big favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it seems impossible to you, but that's one reason why I'm here -- to find cut what makes it impossible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Isn't that very risky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why I couldn't go to anyone but you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (hesitating) I'm just wondering if we shouldn't speak to Captain Iles first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what he'd say. (she smiles grimly and nods) He'd advise against it -- but if it works my way, it may clear everything up -- for all of us -- and for Iles too. The War Department doesn't like all that gold around an Army Post.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) We're working too much in the dark. This may be the only way to see something. It's a risk -- but someone has to take it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (firmly) Who else will know of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just us. That'll be all who know -- and that's the idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (simply) I'll arrange it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Don't look so grim. It's only your gold and my skin. And smile when you walk away as though we'd been talking about what a dry summer it's been.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Bristow is talking. Charlie, looking through the window, sees Haven and Mrs. Caslon part, Haven patting her shoulder with that familiar gesture of his, then coming into the office door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven has entered in silence, seated himself in a chair. Charlie does not look at him; her face, hard now, looks straight at Bristow. He pauses as he glances at Haven with a little nod Haven doesn't return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is sweating a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She whirls and walks out the door. Haven, fumbling for his pipe and putting it in his teeth, follows her with a parting glance at Bristow. For a long minute Bristow sits there alone, his eyes staring at nothing; then as he mops the mildew of sweat from his forehead:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S CARRIAGE - DAY As Charlie and Haven drive in the country. The road winds between hills now and a stream tumbles along beside the winding road. The horse is moving at a snail's pace and Charlie is gazing around at the scenery, relaxed and thoughtful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs. They stop and get out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY FULL SHOT as Haven helps her down the bank to the edge of the water. She sits on the edge of a huge flat boulder and Haven stretches out beside her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...You know I'll always cooperate -- as much as possible. But I haven't the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising and going to the desk with a sheaf of papers, which she places on his desk) These are I.O.U.s for gambling. They add up to six thousand dollars. Do you want to count them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (returning them to her pocket) Your credit's over, Mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My luck can turn, can't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not on my tables.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've seen other people fall in this trap -- but I didn't think it would get me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody does. I'll have Prince drop in and go over your books. Maybe we can work something out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I told you -- CHARLIE That's the way it is, Mark. I pay off on the line and I expect to get paid. Give it some thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you remind me a little -- back there -- of a character I once read in a book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had an idea you'd read a book. What was the character?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon Legree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mark is mixed up. He's either crooked without being smart, or honest without being lucky. And that's no good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I'd want to owe you money -- even if I was honest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was seven I robbed my own piggy bank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hard to imagine you being seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was very fat and ate a lot of candy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that why you robbed your bank?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... I robbed it to run away from home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but I had to go back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It got dark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Haven and Charlie. As she looks at the stream and then at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven has been idly flipping pebbles into the stream. He sees a leaf float by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out his hand and takes hers. Abruptly she starts to rise, very piqued and unable to disguise it. Haven rises too. Takes her hand to help her from the boulder. Then stops and gazes at her, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts down; Haven moves too, but it is he who slips and she who has to catch him. Her arms go automatically around him. His around her. Before he can act himself, she holds him tight and kisses him. It is a long kiss and on it we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL LOBBY - EVENING Orville is strumming the guitar as Haven enters. He pauses as Haven comes near on the way to his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven halts, walks over.
direction.name: direction
