direction.raw_text: He strums the strings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to his room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is my favorite place in the world... I always come here to think about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The rook here and the stream. The stream is always running away and the rock is always watching it go. It's two ways to be -- and I always wonder which is the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They probably envy each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you suppose any woman could envy me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But not a good woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody is any good. You mean respectable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Respectable people are very useful -- but they bore me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With certain exceptions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (curiously) Like who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like Mary Caslon...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we might get to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you happen to know her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew her husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's curious, considering -- HAVEN Considering what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ben Caslon was a very upright citizen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meaning I'm not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (adds thoughtfully) She's certainly not hard to look at -- and now she has the money and is -- (looking away)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: also very respectable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why would she be interested in me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you're no good. And good women like men who are bad for them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Flattery will get you nowhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fooling with her will get you nowhere too -- except in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With whom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The army. Why is it you're always getting mixed up with the army?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (idly) What are the odds I hit the leaf?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (absently) Four to one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pass -- (he flips the pebble, misses) What's the army got to do with Mrs. Caslon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's engaged to Captain Iles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Iles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's the army boss here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) If you're going to frighten me, the least you can do is hold my hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is where you ought to slip -- and I should catch you and kiss you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You finish that song?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my fatality. I never finish nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it's just as well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe so. I thought I'd tell you. Goin' back to your room will be a waste of time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what happened on that buggy ride, but somebody came and took all your truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And, naturally, you didn't do anything about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What could I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could have called the sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MOUNTAIN COUNTRY - NIGHT The stage is now heading uphill, the gentle slope at the beginning of the foothills.

direction.raw_text: . The road is cut out of the side of the mountain, leaving a sheer slope on one side, and high, thick trees and brush on the other. As the stage follows a bend in the road, a rider leaps out and grabs the lead horse. The stage lurches crazily and almost overturns as it slows to a stop. Before Haven can free his hands from the reins to go for his gun, two shadowy figures, handkerchiefs helping the darkness mask their faces, have jumped out onto the road ahead and have him covered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Haven. Haven comes to, gradually clearing the cobwebs. Then suddenly he remembers Goddard and the shot. He makes his way to where Goddard's body lies a few feet up the road. Goddard's right hand is half in his hip pocket, as if in his last dying moment he was reaching for something. As Haven pulls the hand out, he sees that Goddard's fingers have closed around his wallet. Puzzled, Haven opens the wallet. There is a stiff-backed daguerreotype of his wife, an expired Union Pacific Railroad pass, an express receipt, a souvenir bank-note of the Confederacy, and a small, closely- folded piece of paper. Unfolding this, Haven sees the top line: "To Whom It May Concern"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "This certifies that the bearer, James Goddard, is operating as a legally deputized detective for Wells Fargo Stage and Express Company." Haven replaces the papers and lifts Goddard's body, carries it to the stage and places it on the floor. He removes Goddard's gun and shell belt and straps it on, closing the stage door. Haven's face is grim as he studies the ground nearby. The sticky mud shows clearly the new tracks of the bandits' horses. As he starts unhitching one of his horses from the wagon traces, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOUNTAIN COUNTRY - MORNING A tiny clearing on a brush-filled knoll, where the remains of a cooking fire are still visible, the ashes scattered over the tamped-down ground. CAMERA PANS OVER TO Haven, on horseback, as he studies the scene. This is where he evidently made camp for the night. He dismounts, sifts the ashes through his fingers to feel their warmth. He cannot be far behind. Then he turns his attention to the trail loading away. Inspection reveals that it divides, one group of fresh tracks heading towards town, another smaller group further into the mountains. He decides to follow the latter. As he mounts and rides off: DISSOLVE EXT. MOUNTAIN COUNTRY - MORNING A high spot from which Haven can get a good view. Off in the distance he sees:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bandit, unaware of his pursuer, puts his horse and the gold-laden pack horse through the stream. He comes out into a meadow on the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven, as he comes to the stream. Half way across, his horse momentarily loses his footing on the slippery rocks.

direction.raw_text: - bandit. Hearing the noise of Haven's horse, he turns and sees his pursuer, takes a quick shot back at him, then heads for the other side of the meadow where there will be shelter, firing back as he rides.

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - Haven. He takes careful and deliberate aim and fires.

direction.raw_text: Haven's ANGLE. The bandit is almost at the edge of the woods when Haven's shot gets him. He tumbles from the saddle. Haven rides forward, gun ready in case it is a trick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is no trick. The bandit is down where he fell. When Haven turns him over, the man's eyes are already glazed. Haven puts his lips close to the dying man's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man only glares up at him. Haven tries again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man holds Haven's gaze defiantly and silently as the life goes out of him. Haven lowers him back to the ground, rifles his pocket. There are no papers on him, no identification. He stands up. He has the gold back, but he is no closer to rounding up the whole gang than he was before. Unless -- he is looking at the horses, placidly grazing. He goes up to them, ties up the loose lead reins, draws his belt off, and gives them each a sharp crack on the rump with the buckle. They take off across the meadow at a gallop. Haven lets them get a good start before he mounts his own horse, and follows after them.
direction.name: direction

Haven observes several men come out of the main office and snag the two horses.

It is still hidden from sight of the sawmill by high ground between. He puts his horse down the slope towards the approaching wagon, at a tangent to the camp.

direction.raw_text: . MOUNTAINS - DAY This is deserted country on the way to town. When the land slopes steeply from the road down into a kind of wash, Haven halts the wagon. He glances around. No sign of life. He takes a hammer and chisel out of the tool box beside the seat, crawls to the crate and prys it open. His cargo is gold. Satisfied, he replaces the pried board, then pushes the crate over the side. It topples down the bank, vanishes in the brush at the bottom of the wash. With one more glance around, Haven resumes his seat in the wagon, puts a match to his pipe, and sends the horses forward at a faster clip. DISSOLVE LONG SHOT OF POST - DAY DISSOLVE INT. dialogue.raw_text: Well -- what have you found out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddard's body -- shot in the back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And no sign of Haven?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One horse was missing. They might have taken him away on that. They wouldn't kidnap him if they'd killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would they kill Goddard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a Wells Fargo Detective.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see... he was a man they couldn't handle, so they shot him. But Haven wasn't killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He may have followed them on the missing horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he may be fishing for trout in the Verde River. Why do I always learn everything last? Why must everything be common gossip by the time it reaches me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither do I, but I'll find out. The Army didn't banish me out here to set up a listening post. Bring the man in, dead or alive. If he's alive, arrest him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But can you arrest him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I can take any living human being into custody -- or am I mistaken in this too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then go and do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Mark enters in the semi-darkness and pauses, stiff with fright at the sight of Haven sitting in the chair, a gun in his hand. Mark opens his mouth but can't speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Numbly, Mark obeys; then turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark lights the lamp. His voice is small and quavering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark pours a drink shakily from a decanter by his law library.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark gulps his in an ominous silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven puts the gun away; rises, walks to the desk, pours a drink for himself. Mark watches him shrewdly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He saunters to the window -- glances through the crack of the shades. When he turns, he notes that Mark has paper and pencil ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses, looks stonily at the face of Mark, who is staring at him curiously and waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark stares in amazement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. CHARLIE'S SALOON - EVENING Mick is standing outside, holding the arm of Jerry as he talks to the kid. Beside him stands Pete Yore's man, Ben.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Draw those blinds, Bristow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- light it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating gun) Can't you put that firearm away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can -- but it quiets my nerves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'd given you up for dead -- we -- HAVEN (idly rotating the cylinders of the gun) Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, everybody. They found Goddard's boy -- didn't you know that? What happened? Tell me about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I'm glad you got your voice back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're trying to imply that you frightened me, coming here like this, you're right. I'm neither a hero nor a fool. (he sits down) (shrewdly) They killed Goddard -- Why didn't they kill you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody must have wanted me saved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe a rainy day. (dryly) Only it might never rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (himself again) And what do you want from me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to make a statement, which you will write and notarize.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- except that you put it away where it can't be stolen or tampered with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a safe -- HAVEN I can see you have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meaning you don't trust me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do -- but I don't think you trust yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you want it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Caslon has a safe -- a nice fat one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I can arrange it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- here's the statement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I solemnly swear that on Thursday last, about eleven p.m. the stagecoach in which I was riding was held up by five armed bandits. The gold I was hauling was stolen and James Goddard, the guard, was murdered in cold blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I trailed the bandits, caught up with one and -- killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it down. (as Mark obeys) I then followed the horses bearing the gold to a sawmill --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure it was Haven you met?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't I know my own boss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (giving him a shove) Go in and get a beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven finishes his statement. He is again at the window, glancing out. Perhaps he has seen the incident with Mick and Jerry across the crowded street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back into the room. Mark is looking at him with puzzled wonder, his face drawn and tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles slightly. The wonder leaves Mark's face. Urbane cunning replaces it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark smiles thinly, licking his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven lights the pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strolls back towards his room and CAMERA FOLLOWS him, the strumming of the guitar again SOUNDING in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...After I left there, I opened the crate. The gold was in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do about the gold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came to the conclusion that I finally had enough money to need a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (needing a drink again) Have you seen the sheriff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard about him, and I still came to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. Well, as a lawyer, my advice would be -- HAVEN I didn't come here for advice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm wondering what you get out of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It makes me more valuable to somebody alive than dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (levelly) Now I'm wondering what I get out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They been here lookin' for you, the men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought they might.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told them you was out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was. I just came in the back way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You finish that song?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had her finished, but what good is it? It was about your death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it a couple of days -- may be you can still use it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven shuts the door, pulls off his boots and gun belt, lies on the bed and stares at the ceiling. His face is sad and he looks tired. The MUSIC from the saloon comes over, Charlie's song... he closes his eyes and in a moment falls asleep...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MRS. CASLON'S MINE-CABIN - EVENING As iles rides up. He is just about to enter, after dismounting, when Mark Bristow comes out of the office. Mark smiles and nods at the officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark mounts his horse, drives away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Any news about Haven in town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just saw Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (abruptly) Alive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CASLON'S MINE CABIN - EVENING As Iles opens the door and enters. Mrs. Caslon is her usual cool self as she sits at her desk. Iles crosses to her and gives her a peck on the cheek as she fondly pats his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits in a comfortable chair, conscious of the fact that she had ignored his reference to Bristow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles gives her a surly look, takes a cheroot out of his tunic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles is about to yell something at her, then holds himself in check, while she wipes the spilled ashes from his uniform. In this interlude he changes to an icy man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks to the door. She stands there frigidly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and fumbles with the knob, but he can't do it. He turns at last and walks meekly back to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns to the desk and hands him the long legal envelope. Iles takes it and stares at it. He starts to open it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens it, looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands it to her. She reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes back the paper from her, thrusts a blank sheet in the envelope, tosses the envelope back on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iron-faced, he starts out, remembers again, softens against his will, comes back from the door and kisses her cheek and then leaves. CAMERA stays on Mrs. Caslon as she watches him go. She smiles slightly, puts the envelope in the safe, and then from it takes a six-gun, looks at it and begins dusting it with her handkerchief as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You certainly are a careful man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven begins washing his face in the washbowl, and then combing his hair and readjusting his somewhat rumpled shirt. Mark watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a little nervous sweat on Mark's hands; he wipes them on his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little shaken and uncertain, Mark obeys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL - EVENING As Haven and Mark come out. They walk towards the saloon. People look at them curiously. Suddenly, down the street, the sheriff appears, approaching Haven slowly and ominously. Sensing a gun fight, people vanish. Purely from instinct, Mark deserts Haven's side in a hurried walk towards the saloon, eyeing both. Haven comes on leisurely. The sheriff has stopped in his tracks and has his gun out. A woman clutches her child to her skirt. Men stand stockstill, watching. A crowd forms at the entrance to Charlie's. Haven walks slowly forward until he reaches the waiting sheriff. He looks him over with a smile of contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven hands him back the now loaded gun and walks away towards the saloon, leaving the sheriff standing there, a completely dumbfounded and bepuzzled man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S SALOON - NIGHT The place is roaring. Haven enters, followed by Mark. The guy at the piano is playing as always. Haven and Mark go slowly to the bar, eyes following them. The noise softens almost to silence, except the piano, Cowering, Mark sticks close to Haven. At the dice table, Prince stares coldly, hands another man the stick and walks away to the stairway, his eyes seeking Mick Marion who is also staring at Haven. Prince nods to Mick as he goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Good evening, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just passed Bristow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (ignoring this) Why don't you sit down. You look tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I suppose you've heard the news. The holdup and poor Jim Goddard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard it -- last, as usual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (delaying) Why don't you smoke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (taking a match and crossing to light his cigar) I'm afraid you're going to be angry with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puffing) Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON The gold Haven tried to run was from the Argus, darling
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was? (then reacting) Yours!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Now don't excite yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am very calm, and I calmly ask you how you could allow that scoundrel to transport gold from your mine when -- MRS. CASLON The man you call a scoundrel may be dead at this moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he may be in town at this moment -- where, in fact, he is. (looks at her) How you could do this without telling me -- MRS. CASLON I only did it for your sake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: sake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON After all, Mr. Haven represents the U.S. Government.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who do you think I represent?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I told you, George, I was only trying to help you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (containing his fury) And while we're on the subject, who does Mark Bristow represent?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON You know perfectly well that he's my lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know perfectly well he's a scoundrel too. (rises) Is he also trying to help me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at the door, a ball of cold fire) Thank you, Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I'd say that I lost my head if I believed that I had one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON (kissing him fondly) It's my fault George. (turning) Mark left me something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON You're not going to open it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To whom it may concern. That's what it says here. (going on) Well, it may concern me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) My business isn't jammed up enough -- so they send this harebrained demoted lieutenant pry around in it... They want to help me too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON George -- you're getting to be a hard man to deal with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm getting to deal with some hard men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to be. I live a careless life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the deposition?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She has it. It's in her safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we do now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We call on Charlie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a dangerous play, Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if she doesn't believe you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then she'll have to believe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That deposition could be a lie. It might not stand up in a court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're sure of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- not exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. You're a lawyer and you're not sure. Then how can she gamble on it, either?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because she's a gambler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, she isn't. (ready to go) We're the gamblers, Mark. Lot's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're under arrest!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pausing) For what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the murder of James Goddard -- and robbery under arms!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casually) I've heard about you. You don't appear to understand the functions of your office. (taking sheriff's gun and breaking it open) You've missed the whole point of your profession. (showing him) Even your gun isn't loaded. (Haven loads it as it goes on) I suggest that you start all over again, with this point in mind: the duty of a peace officer is to arrest the culprit of a crime -- not the victim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at bar -- as Haven and Mark loan against it. Ernie is looking at him curiously; then towards Mick. Haven doesn't follow the glance, but Mark does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernie gets them. Haven glances at the piano. Mick who had stood there has now vanished. Haven smiles. The drinks arrive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark finishes off his second. A stickman comes up. Nudges Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stickman moves away. Mark looks at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven turns away towards the stairs. Mark hesitates, bites his lip, swallows another drink and then grimly follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gulping his drink) This is no good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The bourbon is just as bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't mean that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just don't like it. (taking another drink) I'm a nervous man. Something's going to happen. I can feel it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why don't we do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're doing something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Waiting for something to happen. (smiling at Mark)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie wants to see you. Upstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mark) See?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I go with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you make it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Charlie is behind her desk, as Haven walks in. Behind him, sweating now, comes Mark. As the two are in the room the door behind them slams shut. Mick is there with a gun. Prince moves slightly out of a shadow. Mark backs against a wall. Charlie looks up from her fingernails. Haven smiles and glances around. His eyes fix on Mick and the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick says nothing, his face a blank hatred. Haven sits down in a big chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another door opens and Pete, the sawmill foreman, enters, stands silently. Haven glances at him, then at Charlie who smiles thinly back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark relapses into a perspiring silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie stares at him a moment. Then she glances at Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete walks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick burns in silence. Charlie smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie is silent a moment. Haven lights his pipe. Charlie looks at Mark, pale by the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks coolly at Mick and Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark glances at Haven who nods and Mark leaves in the wake of the grimly departing Mick. Prince lingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince gets up grimly, his lips tight, the dice held hard in his fingers. He stares at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks out. Haven watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie comes around and sits on the arm of his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She brushes his cheek with her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises and so does she. She picks up a scarf in silence and anger, crosses and goes out the door, Haven following her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I see you found the difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like a board meeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Mark) What's he doing with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I might need a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can realize how seldom legal technicalities annoy you -- but I have one that might. (taking out his pipe) Besides, he knows all about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About a gear box I failed to deliver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know anything! I merely -- PRINCE Shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Mark is right. He doesn't know anything. He just knows what I dictated to him in a deposition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was just a story. About a man who got murdered, a thief who got shot, and a gear box that got lost. Probably nobody would believe it -- (glancing up) ...unless I got killed for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go downstairs, Pete. Watch the stairway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Haven) Who else have you told?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one. Mark I had to have. He's a witness and a notary. He makes it stick. He stands it up in court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (always watching his face) What keeps it from getting to a court?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A cut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's running a bluff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ran one on you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You brought your lawyer. Ask him if this doesn't sound like blackmail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He can't think very clearly in the presence of a gun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it doesn't bother you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) No, it doesn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you want is money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see how going to the law will get it for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you did see how, I'd never get there, would I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it boils down to this: we can make a deal, and all be happy together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not as long as you always have something on us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless you also have something on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how would that be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I deliver the gold to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean the gear box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can even forget I looked inside. So I stole a gear box... I'm still a thief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Mark) What does he get?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He gets even with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you lost your mind!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was all right when he lost his money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right... I'll give him the IOU's... when the gear box is delivered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) You don't realize how important it is when a piece of machinery breaks down. It could close the entire sawmill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I didn't realize it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Haven) You can stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Prince) I think she was talking to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You roll nice dice and you bet them jamb up, but some day you'll slip. And when you do, I'll be around to catch you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I think he will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you should be more careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The poorhouses are filled with careful men... (knocking out his pipe) ...And so are the graveyards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a nice perfume.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Carnation. (she ruffles his hair with her hand) I almost had to have you killed. I'd have hated it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So would I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd have missed you... too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And too long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she smiles at him) Did you ever tell a woman you loved her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you get away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was always in the doorway when I said it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never said it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go over to the doorway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven and Charlie descend. Her face is hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they descend, Stellman can be seen in the bar crowd, watching them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I seem to always end up like this with you. I take you for granted. You like it that way. It goes with loaded dice and crimped cards and fixed wheels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't that your business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Charlie and Haven at foot of stairs. Haven is smiling at her, but her face is serious and her eyes hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven smiles. He can see Stellman approaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts away, but Stellman halts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven looks at him. Charlie watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven stares at him, then looks at Charlie. A slow smile dawns on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pats Charlie's shoulder and then walks out with Stellman. Charlie watches them go. Prince appears beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks away towards the piano. Prince stands there, watching Haven go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Note: Pick up two night exteriors of the post.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You told me once you might be a missionary on your way to China. And that's as much as I've ever found out about you. You're working for me, but for all I know you could be working for somebody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like Goddard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I better bring you that gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me you're still recruiting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, we still want you. But this is a little different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Captain Iles has asked me to take you into custody, Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) You heard the man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Best thing for you is to come along, Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I like -- the best thing for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very friendly with everybody -- isn't he? Wells Fargo detectives, and now the Army. How far can he go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly where he's headed now -- to jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is a sergeant inside facing Iles who sits behind his desk. Stellman and Haven pause at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sergeant exits. Iles looks calmly and with relish at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven and Stellman enter. Stellman closes the door and stands near it. Haven smiles and nods at Iles, then sits down unbidden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles picks up the deposition, extends it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven glances at him, then at the statement, and then tosses it on the desk and inhales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look hard at each other in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven turns and walks out; the door closes behind him. Iles slumps down into his chair. Stellman is smiling faintly at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Stellman turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL LOBBY - NIGHT As Haven saunters in. Orville is, as always, behind the desk. Haven nods at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes and Orville strums a little jail song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY - DAY Haven, driving a wagon and team of horses, is retracing the road he took back from the sawmill looking for the place where he dumped the bullion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Iles) The Quartermaster at Platte wants three sworn statements before he'll replace those seventy uniforms, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Three sworn statements! I told him all I know. They were in the freight office at West Rim City. The building burned down.. .you sure he doesn't want me to send him the ashes too? (seeing Stellman) All right, have Stamm fix the papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice to see you alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dumb luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem to have been living quite an adventurous life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that why I'm under arrest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's indefinite. I wanted to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you consult the Army Blue Book it might enable you to be more definite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Curiously enough, you got me into the habit of reading myself. You're quite right about The Blue Book -- (fiercely)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: that officer should get himself about one-half as far out of line as you have!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How far is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right here in your own statement!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see you did what I expected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've gotten a man killed and Mrs. Caslon's gold stolen. Is that far enough?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising slowly) Haven -- as far as I'm concerned, this deposition is good enough for me. (indicates the deposition) I want these people arrested. This is all the evidence we need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For what reason?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the reason I came here... to get the murderers of two soldiers -- not to save somebody's gold. That's a mistake you made. I still don't know who killed them, but I'm going to find out. And when the net is hauled in, they're all going to be in it. (rising) That's my fish -- and you can have the minnows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (demandingly) When are you returning Mrs. Caslon's gold?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) That's a matter between myself and Mrs. Caslon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't particularly like you -- but I see no reason why you should get yourself deliberately killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling again) It won't be deliberate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What difference does it make how you get killed? Where does it leave me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where does it leave me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (meaning it) Understand this, Haven. You're heading for bad trouble -- and when it comes don't expect any help from me. Is that clear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling thinly) From the beginning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything else, Sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glumly) Yes, three cigars, a pint of whiskey, and a copy of that confounded Blue Book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the good word?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For you it's not good. You're in bad trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how you can know so much and move so little. (turning to go) I think I'll try it myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to leave a call?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's very nice of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you're sure everybody in town is in bed -- call me. And if anybody asks for me -- I went to jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R VIEW of Haven, as he looks for the landmarks. He is whistling softly the tune that Charlie always sings. At last he stops, alights and makes his way down the steep slope, a couple of gunny sacks slung across his shoulder. Bottom of the gulley as Haven gets there and locates the crate at rest in a clump of brush. The crate has broken from the fall. Haven loads the buckskin bags of gold into the gunny sack and scrambles back up the slope. Side of slope as Haven scrambles to the top, he finds himself looking into a six-shooter held in the unwavering hand of Mrs. Caslon. Her eyes are hard and a grim smile plays at the corners of her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven obeys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven turns. She takes his gun and tosses it in the wagon; then glances inside the sack, sees the gold. She backs off a step or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven turns to obey. He manages a smile at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He struggles with the sack, swings it onto the wagon in which he came. Then stands back, looking at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She climbs to the seat of the wagon watching him warily. Haven doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grabs the rein of her own horse, flicks the reins of the wagon team and rides away, leaving Haven on the road, horseless and very much discountenanced. He watches grimly as she rides away. At a distance from him she tosses his gun beside the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S SALOON - DAY As Haven enters. He is dusty and tired from his long walk. The place is moderately busy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Drop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Turn around with your hands up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON All right -- put it in the wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this a hold-up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON You want to put it in the wagon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at her hard eyes) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Now was there something you wanted to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I trailed one of the bandits here where they cached it. I couldn't haul it on horseback, so I came here with the wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON I know that's a lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some of it's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON But not nearly enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try it again. I cached it here myself. I was going to turn it over to them. I wanted to buy a membership in their club. This was the initiation fee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Fifty thousand dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you see, I thought it was worth it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON Well, you see, I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) What you're doing may get me into serious trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CASLON If you're still in town in twenty- four hours, I promise what I do may get you hanged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Haven as he sits tiredly at a table where Charlie and Prince are sitting. She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter exits. Charlie looks at Haven curiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes out the pipe, twirls it in his fingers. The waiter puts down the champagne. Charlie is looking at Haven with puzzlement and curiosity. The waiter goes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her face changes; hardens. She glances across at Prince. Haven watches Prince with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a silence. Prince stares idly at the dice cubes in his hand. Charlie stares straight at Haven. Haven glances at Prince.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince just stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven takes a sip of the champagne, Charlie's whole manner has now changed. It is cold and very quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven reaches in his pocket for a match. Prince, mistaking the gesture, swiftly extracts a small pistol from his belt, covers him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven extracts the match, with a glance of contempt at Prince; then lights the pipe again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a brief silence that punctuates this statement. It has an air of fatal finality, marked by the idle MUSIC of the deaf pianist. Haven puts his pipe away, carefully so that Prince won't get any mistaken ideas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven rises. He brushes some dust off his coat, smiles thinly at Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She says nothing; her face carved out of ice. Prince smiles thinly. Haven looks at him, shrugs. He hesitates; then pats Charlie's frigid shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks slowly out. The dirge of the piano follows him. Prince fingers his pistol a little, tempted. At a look from Charlie he puts it away. Haven goes out. Charlie suddenly leaves the tables and goes quickly up the stairs. Prince watches her with a slow smile, picks up Haven's gun and pockets it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAY As Haven leaves the saloon. He pauses, looks around, up at the sky, then down the street. He takes out his pipe and beginning filling it slowly with tobacco, as Mark Bristow comes hurrying across the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you were in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I talked my way out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a very glib man. You seem to talk your way out of everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Up to a certain point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A gun. (to the waiter) Champagne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are we celebrating something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) You know, the first time I talked to you we had champagne. (smiling at her) I think I should have been a missionary and gone to China after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you bring me something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) No -- just like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's easy to explain. It's just a little hard to believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make it as credible as you can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling grimly) I can't. (filling the pipe) I went to get it, and it was there. But so was somebody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Caslon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... she had a gun with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you have one too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one she had was in her hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This could be that slip you mentioned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Haven) So this nice lady held you up and took the gold, is that it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's like saying I got robbed at Sunday school. It's no good, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at him) No, it isn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I even had to walk back to town. I think that may be one of the longest walks I ever took.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And one of the last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mick might have killed you, but you fought him with your fists. The sheriff had a gun but you took it away from him. Ben had a gun last night but it didn't seem to scare you. Now this genteol petticoat waves a pistol and you run for your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (twirling the wineglass, glancing at Charlie) He makes it sound very silly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or I make it sound like what it is: a lie! (he rises)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling faintly) My word doesn't seem very good around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've only got one thing left that's any good here - and that's some gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) Is that all I've got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite. You've got some time. You've got two hours to get it here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to fatten you up before you kill me? Is that what you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said what I meant -- two hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I once knew a guy who stole a dime tip from a lunch counter and parlayed it into fifty thousand. I might try that -- but not in two hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) You're sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Haven as he walks very slowly, filling the pipe, and Mark comes alongside and walks with him. Haven hardly glances at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've been looking for you. Where have you been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took a walk in the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you get it for her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. (pausing in front of the hotel) Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Haven and Mark outside the hotel. Mark is afraid and puzzled. He keeps staring at Haven's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses as two men walk by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark's mouth pops open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven lights the pipe. Mark stands there, mouth open; fear draining the blood from his face. His voice is a mere whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark stares at him, then looks off. His face becomes grim. He almost glares back at Haven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark stares at him, then turns abruptly away. He hurries across the street. Haven watches him as he goes off in the direction of Mrs. Caslon. Haven smiles and walks inside the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HAVEN'S ROOM - DAY He enters, locks the door. Pulls the shade at the window, takes off his shoes and coat and lies down on the bed. He gazes towards the wall, thoughtfully. He gets up, goes to the window, opens it softly; then looks out. Down the alley, at the corner, a man is lounging; an ugly looking character, whose eyes watch the alleyway. Haven smiles wryly, goes back to the bed and lies down. The piano music starts next door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But that was the deal. You agreed to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're trying to pull something -- HAVEN (finished with the pipe) You want to listen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calming himself) All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explicitly) I can't deliver it because I no longer have it. It was taken away from me by Mrs. Caslon. I've told Charlie, and she's very unhappy. I have two hours to produce the loot. You haven't any idea where a man could raise fifty thousand quickly, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, Mark. The boat just sailed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have to think of something very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can think of something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patting his shoulder with a slight smile) Go ahead, Mark. Go ahead and do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Showing the deaf pianist at the piano, playing. CAMERA PICKS UP Pete as he enters, FOLLOWS him as he walks up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Pete knocks on Charlie's office door, then enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Pete enters. He looks around. Mick is sitting there and Prince. Charlie is standing at the window. By another door another grim character stands in silence. Charlie turns as Peter enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete turns and walks out, shutting the door behind him. There is silence. Charlie looks out the window again. Prince fools with the dice. Mick stands stolidly near the door. At last the silence is broken over the ticking of the wall clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has not turned from the window. The clock ticks. From behind her Mick's voice comes, quiet and deadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick is silent. Charlie smiles thinly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All set.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got enough men at the sawmill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Go back out there and get them into the uniforms. We'll hit the post just before midnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what we're waiting for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave him some time. He's in the hotel. He's not doing anything. I gave him some time. I don't care what he does with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I don't care when, but I'll get him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Mark hurries into the saloon, a desperate look on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Charlie turns from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mick goes to the door, opens it; just as Mark arrives a little breathlessly at the door. Mark enters, a little surprised at the door opening for him, glancing back as Mick quietly shuts it. Charlie looks coldly at the lawyer who is sweating again. Mark stands there, silent a moment, gathering himself together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has turned to the safe; now she turns with them and as Mark reaches for them, Charlie drops them at his feet. They scatter. He bends to pick them up. Prince smiles at him contemptuously. Mark is picking them up one at a time when suddenly he pauses, stands erect, and looks at them with fear and suspicion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark stands there. The papers slip from his fingers. He knows what Prince means. But his mouth hardens in an effort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him the paper from the envelope. Marks takes it and stares at it. It is absolutely a blank piece of paper. He stands there, bites his lips. He looks wearily around at them, fear making him weak, making him unable to hold the piece of paper, so that it floats to the carpet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops dead in his tracks as Charlie moves towards him with a little pistol, pearl-handled. But she only gives it to him. She has to take his hand and put it in his palm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He backs out, the little gun in his hand. Mick opens the door. In sudden relief and haste Mark barrels out. They can hear his quick feet on the stairs outside. Prince looks at Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prince gets up and leaves, and Mick, with a grim smile of anticipation follows. Charlie sits slowly down in the chair. The music comes up the stairs and through the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bristow's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This should be good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mick) Let him in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want the I.O.U's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Did Haven -- PRINCE No, he didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I don't understand -- PRINCE We don't think they're going to be any good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't have anything to do with it. All I did was write it. I'm not in on this. I can still make them good. (he puts a couple back on the desk) Or I can -- CHARLIE What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can do business. (fumbling in his pocket) I got it somewhere. I -- Here -- take a look at this -- the deposition -- (bringing out the deposition) The only copy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Let's have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eagerly) Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Charlie opens the envelope) Nothing. I just want to get out of it. I never had any part of it. This ought to prove that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at last) It's -- it's a trick. I -- (trying to pull himself together) I'll see about this! He can't do this to me! (moving back towards the door) I'll go and see about this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, you see about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take this along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something left to wait for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Haven is lying on the bed, his arms under his head, his eyes on the ceiling. There is a SOUND in the hallway and then a hurried knock at the door. Haven slowly rises, walks to the door. He stands there. The knock SOUNDS again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven opens the door. Mark enters swiftly, the little gun in his hand. Haven shuts the door and locks it. He turns and faces Mark, now pointing the gun. Without a word Haven walks over to the bed and lies down again, looking at the ceiling. Mark follows him with the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven leans on one elbow, looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven lies back with a short laugh. Mark stares at him in fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven again leans on one elbow, looking at Mark and the trembling hand that holds the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark sits slowly back in the chair, beaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven gets up slowly, reaches over and takes the little gun, smiles at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts the gun on the table. Mark's teeth are chattering. He is almost ready to cry. Haven gets a bottle and pours him a drink in a dusty glass. He hands it to Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark gets up waveringly. Takes another hooker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark stares at him. Haven smiles grimly back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark hurries out into the hall. Goes. Haven turns back and looks at the room, picks up the little pistol, smiles at it. Shrugs and then slips into his coat and exits, too.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's me -- Bristow -- let me in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You going to shoot me, Mark?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You double crossed me, Haven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got the deposition back. I took it to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't there! It was a piece of blank paper!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you laugh at me! I ought to kill you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They want you to, Mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it may be your only out, if you do. But I doubt it. You know why? Because even if you took them my scalp, it wouldn't buy your life. You're in debt and you're broke and you're scared -- and you know far too much. There isn't any way they use you -- alive. Can you think of one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to do it. I know it. They're going to kill me -- (his hand trembles) Why do they have to kill me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Us, Mark...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This must be hers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dully) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's one thing, Mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gulping the drink) There is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might get out of town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There isn't a chance in a thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If there's one in a million, it's the only one you have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- we might get away with it. We might...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you can't stay. You said yourself -- HAVEN If you must do this, go straight to your horse. Don't stop for anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a lot of important papers -- HAVEN You haven't got anything important left, Mark -- except your life, and very little time to keep it. You do it very fast and you might be lucky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to pull himself together) Yes. I might be. I'll try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven enters. SHOOTING FROM his ANGLE, we can see, as he does, Mark crossing the street, apparently towards his law office. He is in such a hurry that he falls down, crawls a little, gets up, runs. Just as he reaches the office door, just as his hand touches the knob, a shot rings out and he crumples. He still tries, then his hand slips from the knob and he lies there dead. The vacant street is empty with his death. Haven stares. He takes a match from the counter, applies it to his pipe -- then finding the pipe empty, smiles thinly and pockets it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the little pistol from his pocket and glances at it. The clerk, watching, idly strumming the guitar string.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven smiles. He feels in his pocket, comes out with the army button gotten at the sawmill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk stares at him; Haven smiles grimly. He breaks the little gun, checks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to the door, the little gun in hand; very slowly. Watching him, the clerk twangs the strings softly. Haven walks very slowly. He opens the door and hesitates. Just as he is about to step out, looking up and down the street, there is a furor and the sheriff rides up outside and dismounts. Starts over to inspect Mark's body. He turns as Haven walks on to the street, hands held high.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly; turning to the clerk) You didn't throw away that verse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't have to change it much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't going out there with that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll never get closer to having nothin' -- HAVEN (staring out) No -- I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say -- HAVEN Yeh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm naturally sentimental, bein' a sort of poet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naturally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I keep a bunch of gimeracks -- an oldtime sheriff's gun, a bullet from a dead bandit, a rosary from some guy they hanged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's nice. A hobby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a way -- Want to leave me something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is all I seem to have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking it) Army button. (puzzled) Where's the uniform that goes with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want for -- (he pauses as the idea hits him) Yeh? A very good question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might even know. I think I'll try to go and find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Haven emerges and the Sheriff holds a gun on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Mick as down the street, with disgust, he lowers his gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Prince as from a doorway he watches. Stopping with a shake of his head the intent of a man beside him to shoot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- street -- as Haven surrenders to the sheriff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven obeys, walking up the street -- the sheriff and the sheriff's horse behind him. People watch, appearing now in safety. The sheriff is pretty pleased.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, you -- march.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- of Haven and Sheriff. As they go, Haven's hands still aloft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back of them can now be seen the figures of Mick and Prince and the other gunman, following at a little distance. Going leisurely, now Haven slows his pace so that the sheriff is closer behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven suddenly drops to his knees. The sheriff almost walks over him. The sheriff stumbles with an oath. Haven grapples with him. Haven snatches his gun, drags him by a headlock to the horse, flings him aside and then mounts. A second later he is away. Shots RING OUT as Mick and Prince and the gunman shoot. Haven rides on, bent low, out of town. The sheriff hides his bulk in the dust as the bullets fly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You loaded your gun for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, you! Keep moving!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: from Charlie's office -- as she goes to the window, stares out at the flying form of Haven. A slow smile comes over her face, bitter and grim, yet somehow faintly admiring... She sees Mick mount a horse and start after Haven. Then she turns abruptly away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY ROAD - DAY As Haven slows down his horse, but goes on at a fair clip after looking warily back. He breaks open the sheriff's gun, finds it loaded. He reacts and whistles softly. As he swings his horse off the travelled road to head crosscountry for the sawmill. FADE OUT FADE IN EXT. NEAR SAWMILL - NIGHT As Haven sits on his horse at a point in the woods where he can look down on the sawmill. Around the mill office there seems to be signs of unusual activity. Haven sees Mick Marion going by on the road towards the mill. Mick passes not far away and is riding hard. Haven watches as Mick arrives and Pete can be seen in conference with him. Other men -- too many -- are gathered around. At last Haven dismounts and makes his way carefully on foot towards the warehouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven leaves his horse in the brush and trees and then approaches the building. He finds a window in back, breaks it with a stone; then waits tensely to see if the sound has attracted any attention, gun in hand now. It doesn't. Haven replaces the gun in his holster, opens the window and crawls inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven surveys the piles of crates, boxes and equipment. He starts his search methodically and swiftly. Suddenly a shaft of light comes from the front doors opened now by two men. Haven shrinks back, drawing his gun. The men start to enter when Pete's voice is heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men turn and leave. Haven relaxes. He goes back to work, pulls back a big canvas tarpaulin one of the men had approached, and there before him is revealed the army uniforms, stacked in neat piles. He looks and smiles grimly. Outside is the SOUND of horses and more men arriving. Haven goes slowly around the warehouse now, looking for something. At last he finds it: a can of kerosene. He takes it over to the uniforms, pours it liberally on them. At just this moment a figure appears at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven lights a match and tosses it on the soaked bales of uniforms. They blaze up instantly. The man shoots as Haven ducks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where you guys goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want them uniforms out, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you when.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you think you're doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the shot RINGS out. Pete and Mick, surrounded by many men, turn swiftly. Flame and smoke emerge from the warehouse. They start swiftly across, drawing guns. The man at the door shoots again into the smoking interior. An answering SHOT from Haven fells him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven makes his way back to the open window. He crawls out swiftly. Now the building is in flames. He can hear shouting and, as he moves away, the useless attempt of men to put out the blaze, working with buckets of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven starts for the woods. The flames now light the ground around, and Pete appears around the side of the building. Pete fires and Haven draws and shoots. Pete whirls away, hit but still on his feet, driving forward, trying to shoot again and this time Haven drills him clean and Pete goes down to stay. Other men come up as Haven makes for the woods, disappears. Mick Marion and a dozen men appear, shooting. Mick suddenly changes his mind, turns past the body of Pete, gets his horse and heads back to town full tilt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven watches the flaming building. The slowly approaching figures of the men are illumined in the big light of the fire. Haven smiles, turns to the horse and moves slowly through the trees to a place where he can mount; then mounts and rides for it, SHOTS following him as he breaks into the clear some hundred yards away and heads for the road that Mick Marion took back to town. Bent low, Haven rides for his life -- and makes it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ARMY POST - DAWN As Haven rides up, a detachment of men supervised by Stellman is forming beside mounts in the parade ground. Haven dismounts and starts inside. He glances at his wagon parked outside. It is the one Mrs. Caslon took from him. He smiles slightly as he notes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven walks in, brushes past the desk sergeant with a cursory nod and enters Iles' sanctum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Haven enters. Mrs. Caslon is there, and Iles, in full field uniform. They look at him quickly as he enters; he pauses, glances at Mrs. Caslon and then faces the explosive Iles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Iles stares, dumbfounded, at this impertinence:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles gawks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iles nods vaguely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven dips into a lining pocket under his arm and tosses a paper at Iles. Iles glances at it, then looks, thunderstruck, at Haven.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right. Just barge right in! I'm going to tell you something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (abruptly) No, you're not. You're going to listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lost some uniforms? You thought they were burned?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, they weren't, but they are now because I just set fire to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're smouldering right now in the warehouse at the sawmill, and there are about seventy men down there who were ready to wear them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wear them? What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What other reason? To get in the post and take the gold from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were taking a detachment up north on an Indian scare?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that scare is a fake. A ruse. So you know where to send them now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look here, Lieutenant -- HAVEN Correction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better get down to that sawmill, Captain. They may try it anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: expression slowly changes. He smiles at last.
direction.name: direction
